page.reader:
Birth Order Relationships When did you arrive in your family? Are you the oldest child, a middle child, or the “baby”? Birth order may not be the most important factor in personality development, but we can make some generalizations. If you're the OLDEST, you're probably:
  • successful.
  • conservative.
  • self-critical—always feeling you could do better.
  • able to enjoy the company of older people.
Parents often expect a lot from the first child. They often push him or her to succeed. The first child often has to grow up very fast. If you're a MIDDLE child, you're probably:
  • the one with the most friends.
  • the silent rebel against the family's values.
Middle children often feel less important than their older or younger siblings. If you're the YOUNGEST child, you're probably:
  • a show-off who enjoys the limelight.
  • often the family clown, making everyone laugh.
  • both charming and a rebel—lovable one minute and breaking rules the next.
  • creative in art, music, and other ways.
The youngest child often has the longest childhood.
page.text:
1. Another word for a brother or a sister is a <blank word="sibling" blanksize="Medium"/>.
2. Another word for lovable is <blank word="charming" blanksize="Medium"/>.
3. People who feel they should “do better” are <blank word="self-critical" blanksize="Medium"/>.
4. A person who doesn’t follow the rules is a <blank word="rebel" blanksize="Medium"/>.
5. Artists, musical composers, and writers are <blank word="creative" blanksize="Medium"/>.
6. A person who enjoys making other people laugh is a <blank word="clown" blanksize="Medium"/>.
